1.play: Rodo.: Of such a matter, abhorre me.
notes: Collier: 'Of such a matter, abhorre me.' — Collier (ed. i) notes various readings and punctuation in early texts; the expression shows Brabantio's disgust at the subject mentioned.
Knight: 'Thou told'st me' — Knight and other editors note contraction and gloss meanings of told'st.

3.play: Rodo.: Thou did'st hold him in thy hate.
notes: Staunton: 'Thou did'st hold him in thy hate.' — On the colloquial use of did'st and historical usages.

4.play: Iago.: Despise me — I do not.
notes: Editorial note: 'Despise me — I do not.' — Some texts print 'Defpise' as in older spelling; modernized here to 'Despise'.

5.play: Iago.: Three Great-ones of the Cittie, (In personall suite to make me his Lieutenant)
notes: Note: 'Three Great-ones of the Cittie...' — On the municipal magnates of Venice; see Contareno and Lewkenor for descriptions.

6.play: Iago.: Oft-capt to him: and by the faith of man
notes: Editor: 'Oft-capt to him' — Variant readings: oft-capt (Folio) vs off-capt (Quartos); commentators discuss whether the phrase means 'stood cap in hand' (salaamed) or 'capped' in academic sense.

7.play: Iago.: I know my price, I am worth no worse a place.
notes: Knight: 'I know my price, I am worth no worse a place.' — On Othello's pride and self-valuation; see textual variants and metrical remarks.

8.play: Iago.: But he (as loving his owne pride, and purposes)
notes: Note: 'But he (as loving his owne pride, and purposes) Evades them...' — Commentary on Iago's calumnious picture of Othello as arrogant, and on the collapsed lineation in different early texts.

9.play: Iago.: Evades them, with a bombast Circumstance,
notes: Reed: 'bombast Circumstance' — Definition and use of 'bombast' (originally cotton stuffed; hence 'puffed language') and 'circumstance' as circumlocution.

10.play: Iago.: Horribly stuff'd with Epithets of warre;
notes: Editor: 'Horribly stuff'd with Epithets of warre;' — On Iago's caricature of Othello's style and language.
Knight: 'Nonsuits my Mediators.' — Legal phraseology: 'nonsuiting' in the courts; explanation of the term as used by Shakespeare.
Steevens: 'For certes, saies he,' — Note on the adverb 'certes' and its scansion as disyllable in early usage.

13.play: Iago.: I haue already chose my Officer. And what was he?
notes: Textual note: 'I haue already chose my Officer. And what was he?' — Discussion of the punctuation and quotation marks in various early copies; whether 'For' begins the quotation.
Note: 'Forsooth, a great Arithmetician,' — On 'Arithmetician' as derisive epithet for Cassio: bookish soldier, conversant with tactics on paper but not in field.

15.play: Iago.: One Michael Cassio, a Florentine,
notes: Annotation: 'One Michael Cassio, a Florentine,' — Debate among editors whether Cassio or Iago is the Florentine; discussion of implications and textual emendations (Florentine's, Florentine, etc.).

16.play: Iago.: (A Fellow almost damn'd in a faire Wife)
notes: Critical note: '(A Fellow almost damn'd in a faire Wife)' — Long note on the difficulty of 'a fellow almost damn'd in a fair wife' — many emendations and interpretations surveyed (Theobald, Hanmer, Tyrwhitt, Malone, Theobald's 'Florentine's', Hanmer's 'fair phiz', Theobald, Steevens, Knight, Dyce, Hudson, etc.). (See especially extended commentary on the phrase's meaning: nearly damned by a fair wife, almost degraded into woman, near marrying, nearly damned in his life, or corruption of text: wife/wise/wiifte/guise/strife, with many authorities cited.)

17.play: Iago.: That neuer set a Squadron in the Field,
notes: Note on military phrasing: 'That neuer set a Squadron in the Field' — Explanations of 'set a squadron' and its intended scorn of Cassio's lack of active command experience.

18.play: Iago.: Nor the division of a Battail knowes
notes: Gloss: 'Nor the division of a Battail knowes' — On the word 'Battail' and its several senses; comparisons to Holinshed and other uses in Shakespeare.

19.play: Iago.: More then a Spinster. Vnlesse the Bookish Theoricke:
notes: Note: 'More then a Spinster. Vnlesse the Bookish Theoricke' — Explanation of 'spinster' and 'bookish theorick' as contemptuous of Cassio's theoretical knowledge.

20.play: Iago.: Wherein the Tongued Consuls can propose
notes: Textual/lexical note: 'Wherein the Tongued Consuls can propose As Masterly as he.' — Discussion of 'tongued', 'toged', 'toga' imagery and the contrast between senators (toga) and soldiers.
Walker: 'Masterly' — On form and contraction '-ly' for 'like' in early texts.
Note on 'Meere prattle (without practise) Is all his Souldiership.' — On the sense of 'meere prattle' and the irony of a 'soldier' with only bookish talk.

23.play: Iago.: Is all his Souldiership. But he (Sir) had the election;
notes: Editorial comment: 'But he (Sir) had the election;' — On the narrative point that Othello had chosen Cassio, and Iago's calumny that he did so before the mediators sued for Iago.

24.play: Iago.: And I (blefs the marke) his Moorfhips Ancient.
notes: Note: 'And I (blefs the marke) his Moorfhips Ancient.' — On 'Ancient' meaning ensign or standard-bearer, and its historical usages; references to Comenius, Anchoran, and antiquarian notes.

25.play: Rodo.: By heaven, I rather would haue bin his hangman.
notes: Collier: 'By heaven, I rather would have bin his hangman.' — On Roderigo's hyperbole and social position.

26.play: Iago.: Why, there's no remedie. 'Tis the curse of Service;
notes: Gloss: 'Why, there's no remedie. 'Tis the curse of Service;' — On 'curse of service' meaning the rule of preferment by favour; textual variants and punctuation noted.

27.play: Iago.: Preferment goes by Letter, and affection,
notes: Johnson: 'Preferment goes by Letter, and affection,' — Explanatory note on 'preferment' and recommendation by letter vs gradation.

28.play: Iago.: And not by old gradation, where each second
notes: Abbott: 'And not by old gradation, where each second Stood Heire to th'first.' — On use of 'gradation' and 'stood' as subjunctive/indicative.
Note on metre and elision in 'Now Sir, be iudge your selfe,' — Meter and address forms explained.

30.play: Iago.: Now Sir, be iudge your selfe,
notes: Lexical note: 'Whether I in any iust terme am Affin'd To loue the Moor.' — On 'affin'd' meaning bound or obliged, and moral obligation.

31.play: Iago.: Whether I in any iust terme am Affin'd
notes: Fechter: 'I follow him, to serve my turne vpon him.' — Comment on Iago's candid admission of his motive.
Dramatic note: 'We cannot all be Masters...' — On Iago's rhetorical strategy of universal examples of servile knaves; discussion of 'knaue' as servitor.

33.play: Rodo.: I would not follow him then.
notes: Note on 'Many a dutious and knee-crooking knaue' — On 'knee-crooking' and connotations of servility.
Gloss: 'Whip me such honest knaues.' — On use of the command as ironic.

35.play: Iago.: I follow him, to serve my turne vpon him.
notes: Cultural note: 'For naught but Prouender...' — On meaning 'for nothing but provender' and its implications for a servant's life.

36.play: Iago.: We cannot all be Masters, nor all Masters
notes: Note: 'These Fellowes haue some foule, and such a one do I professe my selfe.' — Iago's self-confession of being one of the corrupt.

37.play: Iago.: Cannot be truely follow'd. You may marke
notes: Dictionary note: 'I am not what I am.' — On inversion of Exodus phrase (I am that I am) and Iago's conscious deception.

38.play: Iago.: Many a dutious and knee-crooking knaue
notes: Knight: 'What a full Fortune does the Thick-lips owe' — On 'full fortune / fall' interpretations and Knight's note on prophetic foreshadowing.

39.play: Iago.: That (doting on his owne obsequious bondage)
notes: Textual: 'Call vp her Father Rowse him, make after him...' — Stage-direction sense and Iago's plan to rouse Brabantio.

40.play: Iago.: Weares out his time, much like his Master's Asse,

41.play: Iago.: For naught but Prouender; and when he's old, casheer'd.

42.play: Iago.: Whip me such honest knaves. Others there are
notes: Stage note: 'Here is her Father's house, He call aloud.' — On stage business and movement toward Brabantio's door.

45.play: Iago.: And throwing but showes of Seruice on their Lords
notes: Annotation: 'Awake: what hoa, Brabantio: Theeues, Theeues.' — On repetitive cry and terror-raising.

46.play: Iago.: Doe well thrive by them. And when they haue lin'd their Coates
notes: Gloss: 'Looke to your house, your daughter, and your Bags, Theeues, Theeues.' — On accusatory imagery: 'thieves' as rhetorical device.
Annotation: 'Brabantio (above): What is the reason of this terrible Summons?' — On stage position 'above' (at window) and actors' movements.

49.play: Iago.: I professe my selfe. For (Sir)

notes: Lexical note: 'Sir, y'are rob'd, for shame put on your Gowne,' — On 'gown' meaning Senatorial or civic robe; discuss Capell and other editors' views.

notes: Commentary: 'Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soule' — On the hyperbolic moral collapse Brabantio imputes.

notes: Note: 'Euen now, now, very now, an old blacke Ram Is tupping your white Ewe.' — On the crude simile and Brabantio's outrage; cultural and racial implications discussed.

55.play: Iago.: For when my outward Action doth demonstrate

Note: 'Lead to the Sagittary the raised Search' — Discussion of the Sagittary (inn or arsenal?) with citations; many editors' views (Knight, Rolfe, Elze) summarized.
Stage-direction note: 'And there will I be with him. So farewell.' — Iago's exit and planning; commentators note his duplicity and plotting.

notes: Textual note: 'On good Roderigo, I will deserve your paines. [Exeunt]' — Final business of the scene and Roderigo's promise; stage exits and scene close.

16.play: Othello: My Services, which I have done the Signorie
notes: Warburton: Warburton, followed by Theobald (not Capell, as Knight says), interpreted this as signifying as large, as extensive, equivalent to the Greek dm7.ov£ t and cited Dioscorides and Theocritus. Whereupon Dr Johnson thus improved the occasion: All this learning, if it had even been what it endeavors to be thought, is, in this place, superfluous. There is no ground for supposing, that our author copied or knew the Greek phrase; nor does it follow, that, because a word has two senses in one language, the word which in another answers to one sense should answer to both. Afanus, in Latin, signifies both a hand and troop of soldiers, but we cannot say, that 'the captain marched at the head of his hand;' or, 'that he laid his troop upon his sword.' It is not always in books that the meaning is to be sought of this writer, who was much more acquainted with naked reason and with living manners. 'Double' has here its natural sense. The president of every deliberative assembly has a double voice. In our courts the chief justice and one of the inferior judges prevail over the other two.
[Further commentators on 'As double as the Dukes.' See main text for detailed scholarly opinions: Johnson, Steevens, Malone, Pye, Knight, Delius, Hudson, Jourdain, White.]

24.play: Othello: May speak (unbonneted) to as proud a Fortune

25.play: Othello: As this that I have reached.
notes: Johnson: Men who have sat upon royal thrones. Clarendon: Seat, thence rank, because people sat at table and elsewhere in order of precedence. See Ham. IV, vii, 77.

Steevens: This has the same meaning, among Elizabethan writers, as merits. [Both Bullroar, 1621, and Minshew, 1617, give Demerit: A desert.] Staunton: 'Demerit' now signifies only ill desert; in Shakespeare's day it was used indiscriminately for good or ill deserving. In the present instance it is apparently employed in the good sense, for Othello could hardly mean that his blemishes might stand without concealment beside the dignity he had achieved.

Pope: It should be unbonneting, i.e. without putting off the bonnet. THEOBALD: To speak 'unbonneted' is to speak with the cap off, which is directly opposite to the poet's meaning. So in Lear, III, i, 14, 'unbonneted he runs.' Othello means to say, that his birth and services set him upon such a rank that he may speak to a Senator of Venice with his hat on, i.e. without showing any marks of deference or inequality. I, therefore, am inclined to think Shakespeare wrote: 'May speak, and bonneted; &c. Or, if any like better the change of the negative un, in the corrupted reading, into the epistatic I’m, we may thus reform it: 'May speak unbonneted; &c. [This last conjecture was withdrawn by Theobald (ed. ii), but proposed anew by Steevens, without credit.] Johnson: Pope's emendation may as well be not putting on as not putting off, the bonnet. Steevens: Bonnier, says Cotgrave, is to put off one's cap. So in Cor. II, ii, 30. Mr Fuseli explains this passage as follows: ‘I am his equal or superior in rank; and were it not so, such are my demerits, that, unbonneted, without the addition of patrician or senatorial dignity, they may speak to as proud a fortune,' &c. 'At Venice the bonnet, as well as the tongue, is a badge of aristocratic honours to this day.' A. C. (in VarJ21): 'Unbonneted' is uncovered, revealed, made known. See a similar expression in II, iii, 'you unlace your reputation.' Coleridge [Notes, &c, p. 250): Theobald's argument goes on the assumption that Shakespeare could not use the same word differently in different places; whereas I should conclude, that as in the passage in Lear the word is employed in its direct meaning, so here it is used metaphorically; and this is confirmed by what has escaped the editors, that it is not 'I' but 'my demerits' that may speak 'unbonneted,'—without the symbol of a petitioning inferior. Staunton: The import we take to be,—my services when revealed [unbonneted) may aspire or lay claim to [may speak to) as proud a fortune as this which I have attained. Even with Fuseli's interpretation it is indispensable for the integrity of the passage that 'speak to' be understood in the sense just mentioned of aspire or lay claim to. Schmidt [Lex.): Perhaps the meaning is simply: I may say so with all courtesy and humility, and Othello's words must, perhaps, be accompanied by a corresponding gesture, as the writing of F seems to imply, by placing the word 'unbonnetted' in a parenthesis. White (ed. ii): The question of manners in Shakespeare's time as to the hat seems very difficult. The remembering courtesy, the off-capping, and the unbonneting are quite incongruous. No attempt to reconcile these expressions has been at all successful.

27.play: Othello: But that I love the gentle Desdemona,

28.play: Othello: I would not my unhoused free condition

29.play: Othello: Put into Circumscription, and Confine,
notes: Johnson: Free from domestic cares. A thought natural to an adventurer. Whalley: To Othello, talking as a soldier, 'unhoused' may signify the having no settled house or habitation. Hunter [New Illust., ii, 282): This passage affords one of the best proofs of Shakespeare's acquaintance with the Italian language. 'Un housed' conveys to English ears no idea of anything which any one would be unwilling to resign; and, in fact, it is only by recollecting the way in which the Italians use Caesar that we arrive at its true meaning, which is unmarried. A soldier was as much 'unhoused,' in the ordinary meaning of the term, after marriage as before. Othello would not resign the freedom of his bachelor estate. Knight: Othello expresses no satisfaction at having been houseless, but he simply uses 'unhoused' for unmarried. The husband is the head or band of the house,—the unmarried is the unhorse-banded—the 'unhoused.'

31.play: Othello: But look, what Lights come yond?
notes: Johnson: I would not marry her, though she were as rich as the Adriatic, which the Doge annually marries. Steevens: As the gold ring annually thrown by the Doge into the Adriatic cannot be said to have much enriched it, I believe the common and obvious meaning of this passage is the true one. Pye: I think Steevens indubitably right, but not for the reason he gives. I believe Johnson thought no more of the Adriatic being enriched by the annual wedding-ring, than Shakespeare did of the Adriatic at all. [Steevens refers to the occurrence of the same phrase in D'Avenant's Cruel Brother (p. 131, ed. Maidment), and adds, 'perhaps the phrase is proverbial.' A citation from D'Avenant, in a case like this, carries but little weight. I doubt if there be an Act in all D'Avenant's plays, wherein Shakespearian phrases may not be found. For instance, the sixth line of this very play of The Cruel Brother reads: 'This way to madness leads,' and 'excellent wretch,' occurs more than once farther on. With more propriety Steevens refers to Wint. Tale, IV, iv, 501, and Hen. V: I, ii, 164; but is again far afield in referring to Pliny's Chapter (IX, 34) on The Riches of the Sea, which alludes to the high prices paid by luxury 'in furnishing the table with such varietie of dishes, in pleasing and contenting the taste with so many dainty and delicate fishes.' Conf. Rich. III: I, iv, 26: 'Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearls, Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, All scatter'd in the bottom of the sea.' Ed.] Booth: Note the frequent reference to the sea;—for the same reason, that I gave anent the 'superstition' in the play.

33.play: Iago: Those are the raised Father, and his Friends:

34.play: Iago: You were best go in.
notes: Walker: Walker [Crit. ii, 202): Thou wert (sometimes written in the old poets Th'wert), you were, I was, &c, occur frequently, both in Shakespeare and contemporary dramatists, in places where it is clear they must have been pronounced as one syllable, in whatever manner the contraction was effected. [See Ham. IV, v, 14, and Aiipott, §461.]

35.play: Othello: Not I: I must be found.

36.play: Othello: My Parts, my Title, and my perfect Soul
notes: Schmidt and Rolfe: Schmidt and Rolfe agree in interpreting this as merits. It seems to me that it is rather the endowments of nature, his natural gifts, like 'your sum of parts in Ham. IV, vii, 74. Ed.

37.play: Othello: Shall manifest me rightly. Is it they?

38.play: Iago: By Janus, I think no.
notes: Warburton: There is great propriety in making the double Iago swear by Janus, who had two faces. The address of it likewise is as remarkable; for as the people coming up appeared at different distances to have different shapes, he might swear by Janus without suspicion of any other emblematic meaning.

39.play: Othello: The Servants of the Dukes? And my Lieutenant?

40.play: Othello: The goodness of the Night upon you (Friends) What is the News?

41.play: Cassio: The Duke does greet you (General)
notes: Delius: May night, usually unfriendly to everybody, show only its good side to you. [Is it not simply the ordinary salutation 'good day,' or 'Godgigoden' adapted to the hour? Ed.]

42.play: Cassio: And he requires your haste, Post-haste appearance,

notes: Booth: Cassio alone knew where Othello was to be found. Othello says, that he knew from first to last of the secret love, &c. Remember this when Iago tells you. 'he's married,' &c.

44.play: Othello: What is the matter, think you?
notes: Ritson: The comma, hitherto placed after haste,' should be a hyphen. 'Your haste-post-haste appearance' is your immediate appearance. The words 'Haste, post, haste,' were, in our author's time, usually written on the cover of packets or letters sent express.

45.play: Cassio: Something from Cyprus, as I may divine:

46.play: Cassio: It is a business of some heat.

48.play: Cassio: Have sent a dozen sequent Messengers

49.play: Cassio: This very night, at one another’s heels:

50.play: Cassio: And many of the Consuls, raised and met,

51.play: Cassio: Are at the Dukes already.
notes: Theobald: Theobald changed this to Couns'lers, for the reasons given at I, i, 27. Knight says, that in both cases senators were probably meant. Th. Elze (Sh. Jahrbuch, xiv, 179): Shakespeare has not clearly distinguished between the Col- Ugio and the Senate. Brabantio's accusation of Othello could not have been brought before the Senate, but before the Ministerial Council—the Collegio. The Third Scene of the First Act is correctly laid in the 'Council Chamber,' not in the 'Hall of the Senate.' Properly also, Shakespeare speaks of 'the Council' and the 'Consuls,' that is, the Counsellors; but improperly in the same speech of the 'Senate' and [line 255] of the 'Senators.' But, perhaps, Shakespeare purposely avoided the use of the word College, because of its ambiguity to English ears.

52.play: Cassio: You have bin hotly called for,
notes: Lettsom: Lettsom (ap. Dyce, ed. iii) would read 'you had been,' &c. Hudson adopted the emendation.

53.play: Cassio: When being not at your Lodging to be found,

54.play: Cassio: The Senate hath sent about three several Quests,
notes: Johnson: That is, about the city. Collier (ed. i) preferred above of the Qq, because a '"quest" necessarily searches in various directions; and the word "about" may, therefore, be considered surplusage. Cassio means that more than "three several quests" have been sent in search of Othello.' But as his (MS) retained 'about,' Collier, in his subsequent editions, followed it.

Steevens: That is, searches. So in Heywood's Brazen Age, 1613: 'Now, if in all his quests, he be withheld.' An ancient MS. entitled The Boke of Huntyng that is cleped Mayster of Game, has the following explanation of the word 'quest': 'This word quest is a terme of herte hunters of beyonde the see; and is thus moche to say as whan the hunter goth to fynde the hert and to herborow him.' Halliwell cites Cotgrave, s. v. 'Queste: f. A quest, inquirie, search, inquisition, seeking,' &c.

56.play: Othello: 'Tis well I am found by you:

57.play: Othello: I will but spend a word here in the house,
notes: Gerard: Gerard: Les expressions to spend et to pay sont a tout moment employees par les Anglais, peuple commercant et pratique par excellence. lis ne rendent pas, ils paient une visite; ils ne passent pas, ils depensent leur temps. En Amerique la premiere question que Ton fait sur quelqu'un, c'est: Combien vaut-il? [When Mons. Gerard enacts the 'Pow'r,' and 'wad the giftie gie us,' shall not we Americans accept it, however startling the revelation? Ed.]

59.play: Cassio: Ancient, what makes he here?
notes: Booth: Speak this with curiosity, as if to learn what Iago knows of the marriage.

60.play: Iago: Faith, he to night hath boarded a Land Contract,
notes: Skeat: A ship of burden. (We also find carrick, which comes nearer to Low Lat. carrica, a ship of burden.) Low Lat. carra- (are, better carrienre to lade a car.—Lat. carrus, a car. Staunton: A ship of large burden, like the Spanish galleon; but the compound in the text appears to have been a dissolute expression.

61.play: Iago: If it prove lawful prize, he’s made for ever.
notes: Lord Campbell: Lord Campbell (p. 114): A very distinct proof that Shakespeare was acquainted with Admiralty law, as well as with the procedure of Westminster Hall, the trope indicating, that there would be a suit in the High Court of Admiralty to determine the validity of the capture.

Theobald: Theobald (Nichols's Illust. of Lit., ii, 586): Surely, this is a terrible forgetfulness in our author. How came Cassio such a stranger to this affair, when it afterward appears he went a-wooing with Othello and took his part in the suit? [Cf. III, iii, 82.] Ritson (p. 227): It is very easy to imagine, that Cassio might wish to know if Iago were acquainted with the lady, to prevent the latter's suspecting that he was. Blackstone: Cassio's seeming ignorance might only be affected, in order to keep his friend's secret till it became publicly known. Malone: Or he might fear that Othello had proved false to the gentle Desdemona, and married another. Steevens: How far this suspicious apprehension would have become the benevolent Cassio, the intimate friend of Othello, let the reader judge. Singer: It was probably a mere oversight of the poet. Abbott, § 274, gives many instances where the inflection of who is neglected. See IV, ii, 115; Macb. III, iv, 42; Ham. II, ii, 193; Lear, IV, iii, 7 and V, iii, 249.

65.play: Iago: Marry to—Come Captain, will you go?
notes: Abbott: Abbott, § 506: It is obvious that a syllable or foot may be supplied by a gesture, a beckoning, a movement of the head to listen, or of the hand to demand attention, as here: ‘Marry | to [Enter /the//o.) | Come, cap | tain, will | you g6 ?' However, we may scan, Marry | to—Come | Cap(i) | tain will | you go,' but very harshly and improbably.
Steevens: Steevens: This expression denotes readiness.

67.play: Cassio: Here comes another Troop to seek for you.

68.play: [Enter Brabantio, Roderigo, with Officers, and Torches.]

69.play: Iago: It is Brabantio: General, be advised,
notes: Johnson: Johnson: That is, be cool, be cautious, be discreet.

70.play: Iago: He comes to bad intent.

72.play: Roderigo: Signior, it is the Moor.
notes: Booth: Booth: This is spoken 'within.'

74.play: Iago: You, Roderigo? Come Sir, I am for you.
notes: Booth: Booth: This is to prevent harm to Roderigo, for whose purse Iago has a tender regard. Make the audience understand this by your manner of singling him out,—look will do it. [See Textual Notes for another instance of the difference between the copy of F x, from which Lionel Booth reprinted, and that from which this edition is reprinted. Ed.]

75.play: Othello: Keep up your bright Swords, for the dew will rust them.
notes: Booth: Booth: Othello's party—Cassio, Iago, and others—should motion 'to draw, when these words restrain them. Brabantio's friends enter with swords drawn. Be very respectful to Brabantio, resent his abuse, merely with a look of momentary anger.

Walker: See Walker (Crit. ii, 321), for an Article, with many examples, on the confusion in the Folio of or and for. Walker would here read or, which may be correct, but of the instances of this confusion, cited by Walker, the present is, perhaps, the least manifest. Ed.
Hudson: If I mistake not there is a sort of playful, good-humoured irony expressed in the very rhythm of this line.

76.play: Othello: Good Signior, you shall more command with years, than with your Weapons.

78.play: Brabantio: Where hast thou stow’d my Daughter?

79.play: Brabantio: Damn’d as thou art, thou hast enchanted her

80.play: Brabantio: For I’ll refer me to all things of sense,

81.play: Brabantio: (If she in Chains of Magick were not bound)

82.play: Brabantio: Whether a Maid, so tender, Fair, and Happy,

83.play: Brabantio: So opposite to Marriage, that she shunned

84.play: Brabantio: The wealthy curled Darling of our Nation,

85.play: Brabantio: Would ever have (t’ incur a general mock)
notes: Warburton: I read culled, i.e. select, chosen. Shakespeare uses the word frequently. Cf. Hen. V: III, cho. 24. 'Curled' was an improper mark of diffr-snce between a Venetian and a Moor, which latter people are remarkably curVd by nature. Johnson: 'Curled' is elegantly and ostentatiously dressed. He had not the hair particularly in his thoughts. Steevens: Shakespeare evidently alludes to the hair in 'the curled Anthony,' Ant. & Cleo. V, ii, 304. D'Avenant uses the same expression in his Just Italian [but as was said before, parallel expressions in D'Avenant are of small avail. Ed.] Malone: In R. of L., 981, the hair is expressly mentioned, and the epithet 'curled' is added as characteristic of a person of the highest rank: 'Let him have time to tear his curled hair.' [See notes in Lear, III, iv, 84, 'A Serving-man, proud in heart and mind; that curled my hair.'—Ed.]

Knight: This Saxon word is used in a plural sense. Dyce [Remarks, p. 233): The fact is, the s has been omitted in the Folio by a mistake of the compositor. In Shakespeare's time dearling could never have been used as a plural. That even Spenser (who antiquated his language more than any of his contemporaries) did not venture to employ such an archaism, is proved by the following from his Hymne in honour of Love:— "in a Paradize Of all delight, and ioyous happie rest, Where they doe feede on Nectar heauenly wize, With Hercules and Hebe, and the rest Of Venus dearlings, through her bountie blest."

86.play: Brabantio: Run from her Guard age to the sooty bosom,

87.play: Brabantio: Of such a thing as thou: to fear, not to delight?
notes: Rolfe: Rolfe: Guardianship, used by Shakespeare nowhere else.

88.play: Brabantio: Judge me the world, if 'tis not gross in sense,
notes: Steevens: To terrify, as in j Hen. VI: V, ii, 2, a bug that feared us all.' The line is redundant in measure. It might originally have ran, 'Of such as. thou: to fear, not to delight.' Malone takes 'fear' to be a substantive, and used for the object of fear; but Abbott, §405, more correctly explains the phrase as an ellipsis, common among Elizabethans, after will and is, e.g. 'I will to the weird sisters.' 'I must to Coventry.' 'I am to thank you for it,' i.e. I am bound to thank you for it; sc here 'such a thing as thou (a thing fit) to fear [act.), not to delight.'

89.play: Brabantio: That thou hast practiced on her with foul Charms
notes: Abbott: Abbott, § 365, Let the world judge for me. This optative use of the subjunctive, dispensing with 'let,' 'may,' &c, gives great vigour to the Shakespearian line. [It is doubtful if 'me' be here the Ethical Dative, as in I, i, 53: 'Whip me such honest knaues,' or 'He plucked me open his doublet,' Jul. Cæs. Brabantio calls upon the world really to judge him and his position, which he immediately proceeds to state. Ed.]

90.play: Brabantio: Abused her delicate Youth, with Drugs or Minerals,
notes: Abbot: Very frequently used, as here, in the sense of plotting, with arts or magic. See Lear, III, ii, 57: 'Has practiced on man's life.'

91.play: Brabantio: That weakens Motion. He haven’t disputed on,
notes: [See multiple commentators: Steevens, Johnson, Ritson, Staunton, Booth, Spence, Knight. All on "That weakens Motion. He haven’t disputed on," and "weakens Motion."] See main text for full discussion.

92.play: Brabantio: 'Tis probable, and palpable to thinking;
notes: Staunton: This is an allusion to the manner in which causes were debated by the judges according to the custom of Venice formerly, Aud it affords, one of many proofs that before writing Othello Shakespeare had attentively perused Lewkenor's translation of The Commonwealth and Government of Venice, written by the Cardinall Gasper Contareno, &c, 1599...

93.play: Brabantio: I therefore apprehend and do attach thee,

94.play: Brabantio: For an abuser of the World, a practices

95.play: Brabantio: Of Arts inhibited, and out of warrant;
notes: Booth: Othello and Cassio exchange smiles of pity for the old man's credulity.

96.play: Brabantio: Lay hold upon him, if he do resist

97.play: Brabantio: Subdue him, at his peril.

99.play: Othello: Both you of my inclining, and the rest.
notes: Booth: Now Othello's friends draw. Othello stands between the two parties with sheathed scimitar held up; its crescent shape lends a little Oriental atmosphere to the picture. 'Tis harmless.

100.play: Othello: Were it my Cue to fight, I should have known it

notes: Wedgwood: In Ham. II, ii, 534, Wedgwood's definition is quoted: 'The last words of the preceding speech, prefixed to the speech of an actor in order to let him know when he is to come on the stage. From the letter Q by which it was marked, "because," says Butler, Eng. Gram., 1634, "it is the first letter of quando, when, showing when to enter and speak." ’ Skeat now gives a different derivation; he says, 'that an actor's cue seems to be the same word as queue, as signifying the last words or tail-end of the speech of the preceding speaker. Oddly enough, it was, in this sense, sometimes denoted by Q; owing to the similarity of the sound.'

102.play: Othello: Whether will you that I go
notes: Walker: This passage is cited by Walker (Vers. 106) as one of the many instances in which hither, whether, &c. are printed as dissyllables, where the verse indicates that they are monosyllables. Cf. Macb. I, iii, ill; Ham. III, ii, 193; Lear, II, i, 53. also m Aubott, §466.

103.play: Othello: To answer this your charge?

104.play: Brabantio: To Prison, till fit time

105.play: Brabantio: Of Law, and course of direct Session
notes: Hudson: The language is rather odd, and, perhaps, somewhat obscure; but the meaning probably is, till the time prescribed by law and by the regular course of judicial procedure.

107.play: Othello: What if I do obey?

108.play: Othello: How may the Duke be therewith satisfied,

109.play: Othello: Whose Messengers are here about my side,

110.play: Othello: Upon some present business of the State,

111.play: Othello: To bring me to him.

113.play: Officer: The Duke’s in Council, and your Noble self,

114.play: Officer: I am sure is sent for.

115.play: Brabantio: How? The Duke in Council?

116.play: Brabantio: In this time of the night? Bring him away;

117.play: Brabantio: Mine’s not an idle Cause.

119.play: Brabantio: Or any of my Brothers of the State,

120.play: Brabantio: Cannot but feel this wrong, as 'twere their own:

121.play: Brabantio: For if such Actions may have passage free,
notes: Theobald: Would Brabantio infer, if his private injury were not redressed, the Senate should no longer pretend to call themselves Christians? But pagans are as strict and moral as the most regular Christians in the preservation of private property. Difference of faith is not concerned, but mere human policy. I therefore read pageants, i.e. if we let such injurious actions go unpunished our statesmen must be slaves, ciphers in office, and have no power of redressing, be things of mere show and gaudy appearance only. Steevens: I believe the morality of either Christians or pagans was not in our author's thoughts. He alludes to the common condition of all blacks, who come from their own country both slaves and pagans; and uses the word in contempt of Othello and his complexion. If this Moor is now suffered to escape with impunity, it will be such an encouragment to his black countrymen, that we may expect to see all the first offices of our state filled up by the pagans and bondslaves of Africa. Heath (p. 534): It is certain from this very play that the Moor had been both a bondslave and a pagan, though at that time he was neither. Malone: In Shakespeare's time page was a very common expression of contempt.

122.play: Brabantio: Bond-slaves, and Pagans shall our Statesmen be.

1.play: Duke: 'Tis oft with difference) yet do they all confirmed
notes: Collier (ed. ii): Collier adopts from his (MS) 'with the same reports,' with the note that 'the clear meaning being, that even when reports of such occurrences are mainly the same, it is often with difference. It appears highly probable that the passage was misheard, as well as misprinted, and that the true text is what we have adopted.' [Nevertheless, Collier returned to F1 in the text of his ed. iii. The Cam. Ed. records 'aim besorts' and 'main accords' as anonymous conjectures. Ed.]

2.play: Duke: A Turkish Fleete, and bearing up to Cyprus.

3.play: Duke: Nay, it is possible enough to Judgement;

4.play: Duke: I do not so secure me in the Error,
notes: Staunton: Staunton paraphrases, 'I do not so over-confidently build on the discrepancy;' but Purnell, with more fidelity to the derivation of the word, ‘‘I do not lay aside anxiety on account of the discrepancy.’’

5.play: Duke: But the Maine Article I do approve

7.play: Saviour within: What hoa, what hoa, what hoa.

9.play: Officer: A Messenger from the Gallies.

12.play: Sailor: The Turkish Preparation makes for Rhodes,
notes: See Appendix, 'Date of the Action.'

13.play: Sailor: So was I bid report here to the State,

15.play: Duke: How say you by this change?
notes: For other instances where 'by' means about, concerning, see Abbott, § 145. Purnell refers [as does also Abbott] to '1 Corinth, iv, 4, "I know nothing by myself" (the Greek being, "I am conscious of nothing against myself"), where Alford quotes, "I know no harm by him," as a midland-county current expression.'

16.play: First Senator: This cannot be By no assay of reason.
notes: For instances of double negatives, see ABBOTT, §406.

17.play: First Senator: 'Tis a Pageant to keepe us in false gaze, when we consider
notes: Johnson: Bring it to the test, examine it by reason as we examine metals by the assay, it will be found counterfeit by all trials.

18.play: First Senator: Th'importancie of Cyprus to the Turke
notes: Rolfe: Used by Shakespeare nowhere else.

19.play: First Senator: And let our selves again but understand,

20.play: First Senator: That as it more concernes the Turke then Rhodes,

21.play: First Senator: So may he with more facile question beare it,
notes: Johnson: 'Question' is for the act of seeking, with more easy endeavour. Mason: May carry it with less dispute, with less opposition. Schmidt (Lex.) from the use of 'question ' in the sense of a judicial trial, deduces the meaning here of 'a trial and decision by the force of arms as the ultima ratio regum.'

22.play: First Senator: For that it stands not in such warrelike brace,
notes: Johnson: State of defence. White (ed. ii): Warlike strain, military necessity or compulsion. [I cannot understand how White deduces this interpretation. The very point of the speech is, that Cyprus is of greater 'military necessity' to the Turk than Rhodes. 'Brace' is, I think, here equivalent to readiness; when a knight had braced on his armour he was ready. Ed.]

23.play: First Senator: But altogether lacks abilities

24.play: First Senator: That Rhodes is dress’s in.
notes: Steevens gives as the meaning here, to fight, to combat, and cites in proof, 'To wage against the enmity o'th'air.' Lear, II, iv, 206; but 'wage' is transitive here; accordingly, Schmidt gives the better interpretation: to hazard, to attempt.

25.play: First Senator: If we make thought of this,

26.play: First Senator: We must not think the Turke is so unskillfull,

27.play: First Senator: To leave that latest, which concernes him first,

28.play: First Senator: Neglecting an attempt of ease, and gaine

29.play: First Senator: To wake, and wage a danger profitlesse.

30.play: Duke: Nay, in all confidence he's not for Rhodes.

33.play: Messenger: The Ottamites, Reveren'd, and Gracious,
notes: Booth here begins his Scene IV, in the Council Chamber. The Duke and the Senators are discovered R. with a Messenger who is kneeling before them. Enter as the scene opens, Gra. Rod. and others. The advantage of placing the Duke at the side instead of at the back as in the old 'set' is, that the characters need not turn theii backs on the audience when addressing the Duke.

34.play: Messenger: Steering with due course toward the Ile of Rhodes,

35.play: Messenger: Have there injointed them with an after Fleete.

36.play: First Senator: I, so I thought: how many, as you guesse?

37.play: Messenger: Of thirtie Saile: and now they do re-stem

38.play: Messenger: Their backward course, bearing with frank appearance
notes: Malone: Used by Shakespeare nowhere else.

40.play: Messenger: Signior Montano, Your trustie and most Valiant Servitour,

41.play: Messenger: With his free dutie, recommends you thus,

42.play: Messenger: And prayes you to beleeve him.

43.play: Duke: 'Tis certaine then for Cyprus: Marcus Luccicos is not he in Towne?

44.play: First Senator: He's now in Florence.

45.play: Duke: Write from us, To him, Post, Post-haste, dispatch.

46.play: First Senator: Here comes Brabantio, and the Valiant Moore.
notes: Walker (Crit. iii, 285): Injoint? Ham. I, ii, 20: 'Our state to be disjoint, and out of frame.' Yet I doubt whether the cases are parallel. [For other instances of the omission, in participles, of ed after d or t, see Walker [Crit. ii, 324), and Abbott, § 342.]

47.play: [Stage direction]: Enter Brabantio, Othello, Cassio, Iago, Rodorigo, and Officers.

48.play: Duke: Valiant Othello, we must straight employ you,

49.play: Duke: Against the general Enemy Ottoman.

50.play: Duke: I did not see you: welcome gentle Signior,

51.play: Duke: We lack't your Counsaile, and your helpe tonight.
notes: Johnson: The late learned and ingenious Mr Thomas Clark, of Lincoln's Inn, read the passage, 'relieve him.' But the present reading may stand. He entreats you not to doubt the truth of this intelligence. Capell: Montano's message to the Senate is worded with great politeness in all the parts of it; in this last relief, the thing he stood in want of and wish'd, is only insinuated; knowing it would follow from them, was belief accorded him. [This emendation of relieve for 'believe,' Collier attributed to Rev. Mr Barry. Dyce and White ascribe it to Capell; White pronounces it 'plausible;' Dyce (ed. iii) quotes Lettsom as follows: 'Believe,' I think right as Johnson takes it. Relieve would mean 'send a successor?]

52.play: Brabantio: So did I yours: Good your Grace pardon me.

53.play: Brabantio: Neither my place, nor ought I heard of businesse
notes: Capell changed this to Lucchese, and justified the change in a note in his usual style: 'The corniptions of "Veronese" may induce belief, that this which we are come to is no strain'd one; and the Italian will call it necessary, terminations like that below being unknown in his language.' 'But,' asks Knight, with more shrewdness than grammar, 'who is the Duke inquiring after? Most probably a Greek soldier of Cyprus, an Estradiot, one who from his local knowledge was enabled to give him information. Is it necessary that the Greek should bear an Italian name? And does not tbe termination in cos better convey the notion which we believe the poet to have h>d?'

54.play: Brabantio: Hath raised me from my bed; nor doth the generall care

55.play: Brabantio: Take hold on me. For my particular griefe

56.play: Brabantio: Is of so flood-gate, and ore-bearing Nature,

57.play: Brabantio: That it engluts, and swallowes other sorrowes,

58.play: Brabantio: And it is still it selfe.

60.play: Brabantio: My Daughter: oh my Daughter—

notes: Malone: It is part of the policy of the Venetian state never to entrust the command of an army to a native. ' To exclude, therefore, (says Contareno, trans, by Lewkenor, 1599) out of our estate the danger or occasion of any such ambitious enterprises, our ancestors held it a better course to defend the dominions on the continent with foreign mercenary soldiers, than with their home-bred citizens.' Again: 'alwaies they do entertain in honourable sort with great provision a captaine generally who alwaies is a stranger borne.'' Reed: So in Thomas's Hist, of Italy, p. 82: 'By lande they are served of straungers, both for generalls, for capitaines, and for all other men of warre; because theyr lawe permitteth not any Venetian to be capitaine over an armie by lande: Fearing, I thinke, Caesar's example.' Schmidt [Lex.) queries whether this be used here as an adjective or substantive; Rolfe inclines to think it is the former.

62.play: Brabantio: I, to me. She is abus'd, stolne from me, and corrupted

63.play: Brabantio: By Spels, and Medicines, bought of Mountebanks;

64.play: Brabantio: For Nature, so preposterously to erre,
notes: Abbott, §13: The possessive adjectives when unemphatic are sometimes transposed, being really combined with nouns (like the French monsieur milord).

65.play: Brabantio: (Being not deficient, blind, or lame of sense,)

67.play: Duke: Who ere he be, that in this foule proceeding
notes: Johnson: Were the man exposed to your charge or accusation. Morel: C'est la un sens tout francais du mot.

68.play: Duke: Hath thus beguil'd your Daughter of her selfe,
notes: Abbott, § 160, gives instances of 'in' used for on. See note on I, i, 149.

69.play: Duke: And you of her; the bloodie Booke of Law,

70.play: Duke: You shall your selfe read, in the bitter letter,

71.play: Duke: After your owne sense: yea, though our proper Son

73.play: Brabantio: Humbly I thanke your Grace,

74.play: Brabantio: Here is the man; this Moore, whom now it seemes

75.play: Brabantio: Your special Mandate, for the State affaires

77.play: All: We are very sorry for't.
notes: Grey (ii, 312) cites a law of I Jac. cap. xii, to the effect: 'That if any person or persons should take upon him or them, by witchcraft, inchantment, charm or sorcery, to the intent to provoke any person to unlawful love; and being thereof lawfully convicted, should, for the first offence, suffer imprisonment for the space of one whole year,' &c. Warburton says that Rymer ridicules this accusation of charms and medicines, but the passage in Rymer has escaped me, and small wonder, in that headlong torrent of amusing abuse of Shakespeare. Warburton, however, avails himself of the chance to cite a Venetian law, Dei maleficii et herbarie, cap. xvii, of the code, entitled ' Della promission del maleficio.' Whereupon Steevens remarks 'Though I believe Shakespeare knew no more of this Venetian law than I do, yet he was well acquainted with the edicts of that sapient prince King James the First.' 'But,' says Ritson (p. 228), 'there is no doubt that Shakespeare had the substance of Brabantio's speech from Cinthio's novel, however he might come by it; and Cinthio, it may be supposed, knew something of the Venetian Statute.' At this line and at line 80, Booth says, Cassio and Othello should exchange smiles, as at I, ii, 95.

78.play: Duke: What in your owne part, can you say to this?

79.play: Brabantio: Nothing, but this is so.
notes: Abbott cites this passage under §350, where examples are given of the use of ' to ' when the finite principal verb is an auxiliary or like an auxiliary, as in Ham. I, v, 18 and 178, and thus explains: 'Here either (1) "to err" depends on "could," i. e. "Nature was not able to err;" or (2) "could not" might perhaps stand for "could not be," "was impossible," having for its subject "Nature to err." In (2) "for" may be either (a) a conjunction, or (<£) a preposition: " It was not possible for Nature thus to err." I prefer (1).'

Johnson: Whoever ridicules this account of the progress of love, shows his ignorance not only of history, but also of nature and manners.… It is no wonder that, in any age or in any nation, a lady recluse, timorous, and delicate—should desire to hear of events and scenes which she could never see; and should admire the man who had endured dangers and performed actions, which, however great, were yet magnified by her timidity.

notes: Edwards [Canons, &C., p. 144): 'Downright violence,' means the unbridled impetuosity with which her passion hurried her on to this unlawful marriage; and ' storm of fortunes ' may signify the hazard she thereby ran of making shipwreck of her worldly interest.… M. Mason cannot understand the ' storm of fortunes ' with ' fortunes ' in the plural, and asserts that we should read either ' scorn of fortunes,' or ' storm of Fortune,' the latter meaning 'not the injuries of Fortune, but Desdemona's own high-spirited braving of her.' Steevens: The same mistake of scorn for 'storm' occurs in the old copies of Tro. & Cress. I, i, 35: 'as when the sun doth light a scorn.' Dyce [Remarks, &c, p. 234) believes that scorn of the Qto was 'no doubt right;' but as an editor he preferred 'storm.' Hudson: The meaning, probably, is the state or course of life which the speaker has boldly ventured upon in forsaking the peaceful home of her father to share the storms and perils, the violences and hardships, of a warrior's career.

notes: Malone: That is, profession. 'I am so much enamoured of Othello, that I am even willing to endure all the inconveniences incident to a military life and to attend him to the wars.' That this is the meaning appears not only from the reading of the Qto: 'even to the utmost pleasure of my lord, i.e. so as to prompt me to go with him wherever he wishes I should go,' but also from the whole tenour of Desdemona's speech, viz: that as she had married a soldier, so she was ready to accompany him to the wars, and to consecrate her soul and fortunes to his honours and his valiant parts; i.e. to attend him wherever his military character and his love of fame should call him.
